title: Between 25 October 2019 and 20 November 2019, how many candidates for the Democratic nomination for president of the United States will cease to be candidates?
preds:
Wow what a finish. In the last minute, Wayne Messam suspended his campaign, on Medium of all places, which is fitting for his shoelace operation.  https://medium.com/@WAYNEMESSAM/i-am-suspending-my-2020-presidential-campaign-but-im-not-finished-yet-60f72ece2b49 The Medium post is dated Nov 19 (Nov 20 is the Medium date, but Nov 19 is the date included in Messam's text). However, the earliest news outlet reports that I see are from Nov 20.  https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/20/us/politics/wayne-messam-2020.html
https://www.cnn.com/2019/11/20/politics/wayne-messam-suspends-2020-campaign/index.html I suppose that whether it is counted or not, the answer is the second bucket. cc. @Anneinak @Chrisp @amory10
I don't see 2 people withdrawing in the next 4 days.
This announcement may hasten one more out. Of COurse Bloomburg didn't make a ripple either.

Further proof that there are no smart Democrats left:  Three more Maybes--Bloomberg, Clinton, and Patrick.  The first one has some chance, the second is a bad joke, and the third has been struck with a bad case of messiah complex.  So instead of losing three out of the clown car, they may add three.   It is always unfortunate to have a stupid government, but it's doubly unfortunate to have a stupid opposition simultaneously.  Alas, the US has been in this unhappy situation since Papa Bush left office.  Ora pro nobis.
Not much time left and so far only Beto has dropped out recently.
Less likely as the deadline draws closer

All of the candidates still in the running see this as an open field and most are actually setting themselves as potential candidates in 2024. They will stay in until febuary then it should narrow down to 4-5
Revising again on the eve of impeachment. At this point for next few days, there won't be any drastic movement as everyone will be focused on trial.

dropping back on 3-4 I thought B;oomberg would enter but not a delyed start skipping Iowa and NH. So for now the field fights to still be alive till the convention
Had he begun his campaign now the field would have winnowed.

I am revising my probability from 67 to 95 for only 1-2 to drop out. The reason is same as listed before and now it has gained more strength for may to stay. Also, many of them have received an auxiliary oxygen from impeachment process that reduces chances for 45 to remain and may help refresh the remaining field.

If Bloomberg comes in, there may be a race for the exits among the lesser lights.  Bernie and Warren will stay in because they overestimate their personal magnificence, very much as The Current Incumbent does his.  Biden will stay in because he feels entitled to the nomination, although his support will vanish as the dew at midday since presumed electability is his only asset and Bloomberg has him beat on that dimension from Day One.  Klobuchar will stay in but only to get the nod for VP, which by the way would be an excellent choice for Bloomberg.   Buttigieg will stay in untiil either he or his True Believers catch on that he is actually less qualified than Sarah Palin.  Some but not all of the loonies will stay in for a while longer, but enough may bail out that I'm bumping the "5 or more" up to 1%.    If Bloomberg decides not to go, I'll have to start thinking again, a process which always begins with bourbon.

I've run a monte carlo simulation using the year to date and distribution of drop out dates for the 11 candidates who've left the campaign to today, and I get an 83.2% probability of no more drop outs, 12.3% chance of 1 more, 3.3% chance of 2 and 1.3% chance of 3 with no occurrences of 4 or more in 2000 trials.
updating with only 1 days left to go, still only one has dropped out.
Based on a short time to end date and the two lowest in the campaign are rich / determined
Other than Castro, not seeing any other candidate dropping out. I may have overestimated the impact of the drop out of a "star" (O'Rourke) on other candidates.
Update for small passage of time.
Shifting to One or two since Beto dropped out.

Castro is changing strategy and pivoting hard toward Iowa [1], which suggests to me that his chances of dropping out in the near future are lower, as he'd want to see how his new Iowa bid plays out. [1] https://www.politico.com/news/2019/11/04/julian-castro-layoff-new-hampshire-south-carolina-065797

Again I used the candidates' travel to Iowa and NH [1] as a gauge of how committed the candidates are to continue the presidential nomination contest.  It is unlikely that the nine candidates that qualified for the November debate to drop out.   The remaining five candidates maintained their travel schedule from September through October, with the exception of Sestak - he reduced travels to Iowa from 12 to 1.  But then he increased his travel to NH from 6 to 24 indicating he is still in but is redirecting his efforts to NH.  So none of these candidates will drop out before Nov 20. So I forecast 100% between one or two - O'Rourke already dropped out. [1]  https://ballotpedia.org/Presidential_candidate_campaign_travel,_2020

My previous update today didn't take proper consideration of the probabilities. There's a good chance of either 0 or 1 new withdrawals over the next 20 days, but also a relatively decent chance of more than 1. I feel like I'm still erring a bit too much in favour of 1 or 2, and that the chances of > 2 are higher than 25%, but at the same time I find myself gaming the system in my head and being influenced by self-talk... :-)

Updating to reflect the passage of time and one withdrawal so far (Beta O'Rourke). This year so far, 11 candidates have withdrawn, or about one per month, so the most likely occurrence over the next 20 days is 2/3 of another withdrawal.
One already did so I'm shifting my forecast to reflect that.

https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-50268843
The clown car is leaking more slowly than I anticipated; not sure why.  This story has Harris on the ropes as well.    It seems the Ds are still working very hard to find a way to lose in '20.  This is too bad for me as a Republican because it sets my teeth on edge every time a press story refers to The Current Incumbent as a "Republican."

Castro reportedly raised 90% of his “do or die” (too much Brexit news you say?) fundraising goal by the morning of Oct 31. Maybe last minute donations even got him above the target by the end of the day. He also just got a flattering profile in Time. I am guessing those two factors forestall his drop out in the short term. https://time.com/5714603/julian-castro-progressive-campaign/

Two candidates closest on my radar for dropping out are Messam and Sestak. Messam: Recently "Messam said of his candidacy, “I’m still technically in the race.”" [1]. He is doing virtually no traveling in early primary states and his campaign financing is close to non-existent [1]. His comment above makes it seem like he can't be bothered to suspend his campaign, as also argued in [2]: "Messam and Sestak don’t really have campaigns visible enough to shut down, so why bother?" Sestak: He has actually been campaigning recently in Iowa and earlier in October in NH, and got a recent profile in Christian Science Monitor [3]. He hasn't made recent assertions or commitments to stay in the race despite opportunities to do so when interviewed by journos writing stories about his no-hope candidacy [4] which makes me think he is starting to see the writing on the wall. [1] https://ballotpedia.org/Wayne_Messam_presidential_campaign,_2020, also see: https://www.latimes.com/politics/story/2019-10-17/democrat-mayor-wayne-messam-presidential-campaign
[2] http://nymag.com/intelligencer/2019/10/why-havent-more-democratic-candidates-dropped-out.html
[3] https://ballotpedia.org/Joe_Sestak_presidential_campaign,_2020
[4] https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2019/oct/24/zero-support-the-democratic-presidential-candidate-who-refuses-to-give-up

The first few times this question was asked, I carefully weighed each candidate to evaluate their polling, financial position, and path forward. I then watched as far fewer candidates than predicted dropped out and realized I forgot to account for the ego a person who thinks they can run for president . Based on that I am throwing all the analysis out the window and just saying maybe one or two candidates' financial situation will be so dire that they will have to suspend their campaigns. Seems unlikely because Joe Sestak is still running for more quixotic reason so only 30%.

Only nine candidates have qualified for the November debate so far, and perhaps only one or two more will qualify by the Nov 13 deadline. https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2019/10/14/who-has-qualified-november-democratic-debate/?arc404=true

Thank you Smitch15 for the correction, I had some things wrong. I have adjusted my forecast. I don't see many candidates dropping out before the next debate (11/20). There are 7 planned debates after this one. The first state primaries aren't until February 2020. As such, it is still early in the primary. As of 10/24, 9 candidates have qualified [1]. It is unlikely that they will drop out.  Of the 9 that do not qualify for the next debate, I believe that maybe one or two more will cross the necessary threshold. Of those that do not qualify, I think majority will stick it out through the forecast window. As it is still early in the primary schedule. Due to the depth of the field, it is likely that some will drop out. I do not think more than 4 will drop out. Based on the patterns before past debates, few candidates dropped out prior to the debates.  [1] https://ballotpedia.org/Democratic_presidential_primary_debate_(November_20,_2019)

As of 10/29 Tulsa Gabbard has dropped out. So 1. The others will start to drop as power consolidates. However, the convention isnt until July so the top candidates will jockey for position in the party and the cabinet.

According to https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/klobuchar-is-the-ninth-candidate-to-make-the-november-debate/, only 9 candidates qualified for the Nov 20 debate. Only 1-3 are likely to meet the criteria to qualify. I guess candidates who do not qualify doesn't have to quit but it seems a reasonable expectation since those candidates have not had much traction since they joined the race.

My analysis would actually show show 67% possibility for 3 to 4 drop out and 33% possibility for 1 to 2 drop out. However, interestingly for some reason (Impeachment, Obama's position at this point, let elders fight and lose oxygen strategy :) ), most of them want to hang around silently and watch how things go. Lower polled candidates try to conserve energy and money to see top ones fight each other.
There are currently (as of four days ago) 17 candidates, and 7 have already dropped out.

Just getting on this site and I want to test how this works. ==Reasoning so far==
According to wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries#Debates
There are no debates since then. And from reading crowd forecast and the top commentors' results == Questions I will answer later==
- Who is most likely to withdraw? Have they talked about it?
(Anneinak answered this one, need to verify: Julián Castro)
- What is the average attrition rate of nominees in the past? When? Why?
(Emil answered this one; I need to verify: As previously calculated, the base rate based on previous elections since the 80s is about 1-2 per month)
- What attributes influence dropping? (money? getting on debates? etc. How likely are these mapped to each candidate? ===
Other resources:
https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/klobuchar-is-the-ninth-candidate-to-make-the-november-debate/

Basing my thoughts on the outline provided by @Anneinak. However, I disagree a bit on the categories broadly, and I have a conceptual concern as well.  Broadly, I think the only candidates who may withdraw during this period are Julián Castro, Michael Bennet, Steve Bullock, John Delaney, Wayne Messam, Joe Sestak, Marianne Williamson, Beto O’Rourke, and Tulsi Gabbard.  Given that the other candidates have qualified for the November 20th debate, there is no reason for them to call it quits (assuming no health issues). Debates are free press, free time to get ones name out, time to pander to the party, and, broadly, help yourself out going forward. I think it is highly likely Beto and Tulsi make the threshold and even if they don't I think they will stick around given how conceptually wide open the race is. In addition, it seems from this article [1] that these candidates have until November 13th to try to get enough support to make the cut-off. That means that failing to do so only gives Beto and Tulsi one week to quit.  My conceptual concern, is that conditional on one candidate retiring, I think the probability of other candidates retiring goes way up. Even if we expect 1 or 2 to retire each month on average, I would expect it to come in bunches, 3 one month, 0 the next. This is because a candidate retiring illustrates that donors are pulling back for fringe candidates or DNC is pressuring candidates to quit or whatever. These factors should affect all candidates, not just one.  So, I think the most likely scenario is no candidate quits during this period. If one quits, I think it is likely a few will. My one concern is that Castro seems to be playing a different game than the other candidates so I think it is also definitely possible he calls it quits and no one else does (hence one to two being greater than three to four). But, if one of the fringe candidates quits, I will shift most of my weight to three or four rather than to one or two.  [1] https://democrats.org/news/dnc-announces-qualification-criteria-for-fifth-presidential-primary-debate/

Most likely to withdraw  . . . have even spoken of it:
Julián Castro,  Next most likely to withdraw because they didn't qualify for the October or (so far) the November debate

Cory BOOKER

Amy KLOBUCHAR  No way do I think these candidates will withdraw

Joe BIDEN
Pete BUTTIGIEG
Elizabeth WARREN Candidates who have qualified for the Nov debate have their last name in caps. Adjusted based on info from https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/klobuchar-is-the-ninth-candidate-to-make-the-november-debate/

Found this to be a useful resource on base rates for candidate dropout rates:
https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/some-of-todays-candidates-probably-wont-make-it-to-iowa/ In a large field (>10 candidates), the overall dropout rate ahead of Iowa averages about a third, and the larger the field, the faster the dropouts tend to come (though the article notes some reasons why the 2020 Democratic candidates may be more tenacious). Original field = 26
Already dropped out = 8
Suggests another 1-2 to go at some point before Iowa.

Julián Castro +

Michael Bloomberg (entered 11/21) EDIT:  Candidates who have qualified for the Nov debate have their last name in caps. EDIT 2 (10/30)   Harris, who I have listed in one of the least likely to withdraw groups, is firing dozens of staff, reducing pay for others, and sending a bunch of people to Iowa because her burn rate was 125%.  Interestingly, these changes have not impacted her South Carolina team/staff which suggests to me that she intends to stay in the race until SC. EDIT 3 (111/5)  * Indicates candidates who qualify for the Dec debate. 
                          + Indicates partially qualified for Dec debate EDIT 4 (11/12)  Gabbard qualified for Nov debate EDIT 5 (11/22)  Messam withdrew;

                        Harris withdrew today.

                        Move Booker back to group 1 (reversing 11/22). EDIT 8 (12/6)  +Castro partially qualified for Dec debate. EDIT 9 (12/11)  *Yang qualified for Dec debate

It all comes down to how expensive these campaigns are and how successful (or not) each candidate is at getting funds.  Julian Castro has already indicated that needs to raise money by the end of the month or will need to drop out.  Also, Joe Biden, Elizabeth Warren, Pete Buttigieg, and Bernie Sanders have all far out paced other candidates in terms of raising campaign funds.  I think it's likely that at least one candidate or possibly two will withdraw. https://www.businessinsider.com/how-much-money-2020-democrats-candidates-have-raised-fundraising-2019-4#andrew-yang-10-million-11
https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2019/10/21/julian-castro-tells-supporters-he-needs-800-000-hell-end-his-2020-bid/4052737002/

~~~
Outside View
~~~ As previously calculated, the base rate based on previous elections since the 80s is about 1-2 per month [1] ~~~
Inside View
~~~ Tim Ryan , one of the fringe candidates most “at risk” of qualifying for this question, recently dropped out. Many other fringe candidates have committed to stay despite not qualifying for the latest debates [1]. The recent decline of Biden (in the polls) and Bernie Sanders (with respect to questions about his health) likely keep the hope alive for many of the fringe candidates.  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/907168
